events.description: Showing at The Ross March 13-26. Visit theross.org for tickets, show times, and more information. From writer-director Oliver Laxe (Fire Will Come, Mimosas) comes an explosive and transformative descent into the Moroccan desert, where a Spanish father and his young son infiltrate an underground rave scene in search of a missing girl.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Escalante Canyons Backpacking
events.description: Have you ever wanted to explore the beautiful orange and red canyons, natural arches and desert of the American Southwest? This is the adventure for you! On this trip we will head deep into the canyons of the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument on a five-day backpacking expedition. You will be fully present and immersed in nature as we carry all of our own gear, cook savory backcountry meals, and have great conversations under the stars. We will finish the trip by spending a day exploring and hiking in a National Park. Join us for an unforgettable Spring Break in the awe-inspiring desert southwest! No prior backpacking experience is necessary, and there are many first-time adventurers who have done this trip, though keep in mind is that backpacking is a serious physical activity where you will spend hours walking most days. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 13-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 6:30-8:00pm March 4 & 11, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $495 for students/members $745 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break National Parks Hiking Tour
events.description: Join us for a week of exploring the breathtaking National Parks of the American Southwest on this new Outdoor Adventures trip! We will spend a week hiking in Zion, Canyonlands, and Arches National Parks as well as exploring lesser known, but just as beautiful trails in the surrounding desert. We will be touring the parks on foot, spending the majority of our days hiking to scenic views and overlooks (with plenty of time to soak in the scenery and take pictures). Each night we will cook and camp together as we share stories of that day’s adventure. This is the perfect trip for someone looking to get into hiking and outdoor adventures as well as seasoned explorers interested in checking new National Parks off their bucket list. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 13-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 8:00-9:30pm March 4 & 11, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $525 for students/members $774 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Rio Grande Canoeing
events.description: One word best describes the canyons of West Texas: remote. If you’re seeking a real adventure, you won’t find a better alternative to this Spring Break trip. This trip is a great chance to slow down and decompress, as we spend multiple days on the river, with no resupplies or stops at restaurants in between the put-in and the take-out. You’ll have some great conversations with new friends as you paddle in the tight canyons forged by iconic watersheds of the remote desert and explore side canyons or remains of villages. Find something worth telling stories about when you return from break. Given the remoteness and challenging rapids of this trip, this trip will require participants to be actively involved in paddling and learning how to navigate the rapids. This trip is an opportunity to work through challenges as a team and do significant physical exercise over spring break. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 12-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 7:00-9:00pm March 2 & March 9, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $495 for students/members $745 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Million Dollar Baby (Nebraska at the Oscars)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theater (Room 124)
events.description: Join us March 10-15 for a celebration of Oscar-winning films with a Nebraska connection! TICKETS: $10 General Admission | $5 Members & UNL Students Frankie Dunn (Clint Eastwood) is a veteran Los Angeles boxing trainer who keeps almost everyone at arm's length, except his old friend and associate Eddie "Scrap Iron" Dupree (Morgan Freeman). When Maggie Fitzgerald (Hilary Swank) arrives in Frankie's gym seeking his expertise, he is reluctant to train the young woman, a transplant from working-class Missouri. Eventually, he relents, and the two form a close bond that will irrevocably change them both. (2005 / 2 hours, 12 minutes / Rated PG-13)Ross SeriesStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Angels Theatre Company's The Rocket Men
events.location: Lied Center for Performing Arts Room:Carson Theater
events.description: Six women step into the roles of the former Nazis who sent us to the moon to share with us a story about the team that formed the backbone of NASA in the most unlikely of places...North Alabama. Told through the point of view of Heinz- Hermann Koelle, a lesser-known young German rocketeer, who joined this “Operation Paperclip” team several years later, the play explores the dynamic relationship of Wernher von Braun and Koelle as these two have set their sights on space exploration and colonization beyond the moon. Still, as the play counts down to the launch of Apollo 11, Koelle is befriended by a Jewish engineer who is hell-bent on exposing the truth: the Germans’ technology is based on the V-2 rockets built by slave labor more tied to Koelle’s world than he can imagine. A startling new play about the intersection of scientific exploration and moral responsibility, The Rocket Men asks what it means “to be an American”. The Rocket Men is a new play by award-winning playwright Crystal Skillman. This unique production is part of a National New Play Network Rolling World Premiere happening across the country with The Phoenix Theatre, Synchronicity Theatre, and Angels Theatre.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Who I Am: Self-Portrait Workshop
events.description: Participants will spend time in the exhibition "Hyphen American: Intersections of Identity," examining the ways artists express identity and personal experience through portraiture. This discussion will provide the foundation for a mixed-media artwork incorporating photography during a self-portrait workshop led by Sheldon educators Jordan Nova and Sydney DeRoin. Each participant will create and take home an original piece that includes a photograph taken at the beginning of the session. This program is free and open to individuals 16 years and older. Space is limited and registration is required. Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Colorado Snowshoeing
events.description: Program Date: Overnight Program from March 15-20, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meeting: 6:00-8:00pm March 10, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 It may be March, but the winter adventures continue in Colorado! Join us for a week of snowshoeing and exploring a National Park on this new Spring Break trip. With a cozy mountain cabin as our home base, we will first strap on our snowshoes and traverse the scenic Rio Grande National Forest in the San Juan Mountains. We will then finish our adventure with a day at the famous Great Sand Dunes National Park. Be ready for fun days on the snow and ice followed by nights filled with star gazing and board games around the wood stove. We will teach you everything you need to know, so no prior snowshoeing experience is necessary. This trip is perfect for someone who wants to try new adventures, build close friendships, and doesn’t mind the cold. $355 for students/members $605 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Obex
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross March 13-19. Visit theross.org for tickets, showtimes, and more information. In pre-internet 1987, Conor and his dog Sandy live a life of seclusion, lost in the slow-rendering graphics of early Macs and televisions aglow with late night horror movie marathons. But when he begins playing OBEX, a new and mysterious, state-of-the-art computer game, he finds himself trapped in a low-tech, but high-stakes analog hellscape as the line between reality and game blurs. Audacious and uncanny, writer-director Albert Birney's OBEX is a delightfully skewed lo-fi fantasy. Shot in striking black and white, this surreally nostalgic nightmare revisits the dawn of personal computing to reflect on the loneliness of our always-online present day.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Genealogy Over Lunch
events.description: Do you have family papers and photos that you don't know how to preserve? Join Karen Keehr, executive director and archivist at the American Historical Society of Germans from Russia, as she gives you the tricks and tips on how to start and organize your very own personal archive. March 17th from 11:30-12:30, on Zoom. Registration required. Karen Keehr, Executive Director/Archivist, joined the American Historical Society of Germans from Russia in June 2022 with over 25 years of experience in the Archives field. She has specialized training in digital imaging and photograph preservation. One of her goals at AHSGR is to increase access to our unique German Russian collections through digital access and improved archival processing. Before her current position, Keehr was an archivist with the Nebraska State Historical Society.Preserve your family papers and photosStatus: CONFIRMED | -

events.description: University employees are encouraged to register for this free group fitness class! To learn more about this class and to register click the link below. Status: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
events.description: Wellness Recovery Action Plan or WRAP is an evidence-based practice that helps individuals develop a personalized wellness and crisis plan. WRAP takes a strengths-based approach to help individuals take control of their well-being and increase awareness and management of health concerns. Through the course of the group, members will develop their own WRAP and learn skills to support their wellbeing. This is an open group, and members can join at any session. Members are encouraged to continue until all sections of their WRAP are completed.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Alcohol and Drug Harm Reduction Group
events.description: This group is offered to anyone that wants to make positive changes to their substance use. Abstinence is not required, although individuals committed to a sober lifestyle are welcome to attend. Whatever your goals are, the choice is yours for how you want to engage in the group. We foster the philosophy that every person is unique and may be in different places with their alcohol and drug use. Therefore, respect and openness to these differences is paramount to how the group is conducted.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Piece by Piece
events.description: Building connections in college can feel challenging, especially when you are feeling overwhelmed. Good news - you don't have to do it alone! Piece by Piece is a group focused on using board games as a fun and low-pressure way to explore interpersonal skills, manage emotions, and develop healthy ways of relating to others. Each session offers an opportunity to learn, reflect, and engage at your own comfort level - no pressure to share or participate beyond what feels comfortable to you. This is an open, drop-in group. Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: NRICH: AI Advantage
events.description: Ready to move beyond the basics? This session helps you turn AI into a real work partner, not just a novelty. Mel will share practical workflows, advanced prompt strategies, and smart ways to get more accurate, useful results while saving time and reducing mental load. Presenter Bio: Mel Sedlacek is an Office Associate & IDEA Campus Coordinator in CYAF at UNL. Specializing in leveraging AI to streamline workflows, enhance productivity, and support decision-making in higher education. Their expertise lies in AI education, AI-assisted teaching, prompt engineering, and AI integration in administration. She has led workshops on AI literacy, prompt writing, AI for education, efficiency tools for staff, helping faculty and staff understand and implement AI solutions in their daily work. Passionate about making AI accessible, they focus on bridging the gap between emerging technologies and practical applications that improve efficiency and innovation. They believe that thoughtful AI use can empower professionals to work smarter, not harder-a philosophy that guides their work in CYAF. The University of Nebraska-Lincoln is committed to accessibility in our events and programs. We provide accommodations for individuals with disabilities to participate effectively and safely. To request an accommodation, please contact Organizational Development and Training by phone at 402.472.3790 or email at training@unl.edu. events.title: Grief Group
events.description: Grief can be an isolating experience. You don't have to go through it alone. CAPS is hosting a weekly Grief Group where all students can find a safe and supportive space to process the death of a friend, family member, or loved one with peers who have had similar experiences. Grief Group will learn about grief, explore and process grief's complex emotions, and learn healthy ways to cope. There is no pressure to share or engage, as we are all at different stages in our grieving journey.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Intro to Advanced Reviews Research Methods
events.description: Learn the difference between Systematic Reviews, Scoping Reviews, and Qualitative Evidence Syntheses. This workshop will discuss the similarities and differences between them and when it might be appropriate to use one over the other. Learn how the literature distinguishes between them to make your review more publishable. Participants will learn how to choose the right methodology for the research question they are asking, and how to tailor a research question to match the methodology they’d like to use. The workshop will also touch on tools and when and how they may help you in the process and when AI can be helpful, and where it is harmful in the review process. This workshop will be recorded. Contact Elle Covington if you would like to receive the recording.Status: CONFIRMED | -

events.title: Growing Conservation: Urban Agriculture in Action
events.description: Discover how urban agriculture is making a real impact on soil health, water quality, biodiversity, and climate resilience right here in the metro area! Join Nebraska Extension, Conservation Nebraska, and metro Omaha local foods partners for an engaging presentation and panel discussion featuring practitioners working at the intersection of food systems and environmental stewardship. You'll walk away with practical, concrete ways to get involved in conservation through growing, reducing waste, and strengthening community action. Panelists include: * Jody Green - Urban Entomologist, Nebraska Extension * Dana Freeman - Urban Agriculture Instructor, Nebraska Extension * Alex O'Hanlon - Local Foods Engagement Coordinator * Grant Daily - Planner, City of Omaha * Stephanie Finklea - Owner, Black Chick Farm & Omaha Sunflower Cooperative * Ingrids Mata - Conservation & Soil Health Program Manager, City Sprouts Register here: https://go.unl.edu/uainaction Learn more: https://go.unl.edu/growingconservation Let's grow food-and conservation-together! Status: CONFIRMED | -

events.title: Yoga for Climbers
events.description: Join UNL’s Outdoor Adventures every Wednesday at Yoga for Climbers! Yoga for Climbers will complement your climbing goals and is great for your general wellness. This class focuses on using yoga to enhance climbing performance by improving flexibility, breath control, balance, and strengthening stabilizing muscles.Climbing Wall ClinicsStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Angels Theatre Company's The Rocket Men
events.location: Lied Center for Performing Arts Room:Carson Theater
events.description: Six women step into the roles of the former Nazis who sent us to the moon to share with us a story about the team that formed the backbone of NASA in the most unlikely of places...North Alabama. Told through the point of view of Heinz- Hermann Koelle, a lesser-known young German rocketeer, who joined this “Operation Paperclip” team several years later, the play explores the dynamic relationship of Wernher von Braun and Koelle as these two have set their sights on space exploration and colonization beyond the moon. Still, as the play counts down to the launch of Apollo 11, Koelle is befriended by a Jewish engineer who is hell-bent on exposing the truth: the Germans’ technology is based on the V-2 rockets built by slave labor more tied to Koelle’s world than he can imagine. A startling new play about the intersection of scientific exploration and moral responsibility, The Rocket Men asks what it means “to be an American”. The Rocket Men is a new play by award-winning playwright Crystal Skillman. This unique production is part of a National New Play Network Rolling World Premiere happening across the country with The Phoenix Theatre, Synchronicity Theatre, and Angels Theatre.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Bitter Rice (4K Restoration)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: ONE NIGHT ONLY ~ Wednesday, March 18 @ 7:30 p.m. Visit theross.org for tickets and more information. During planting season in Northern Italy's Po Valley, an earthy rice-field worker (Silvana Mangano) falls in with a small-time criminal (Vittorio Gassman) who is planning a daring heist of the crop, as well as his femme-fatale-ish girlfriend, played by the Hollywood star Doris Dowling. Both a socially conscious look at the hardships endured by underpaid field workers and a melodrama tinged with sex and violence, this early smash for producer extraordinaire Dino De Laurentiis and director Giuseppe De Santis is neorealism with a heaping dose of pulp. TICKETS: $10 General Admission | $5 Friends Members & UNL Students.Ross EventStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Colorado Snowshoeing
events.description: Program Date: Overnight Program from March 15-20, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meeting: 6:00-8:00pm March 10, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 It may be March, but the winter adventures continue in Colorado! Join us for a week of snowshoeing and exploring a National Park on this new Spring Break trip. With a cozy mountain cabin as our home base, we will first strap on our snowshoes and traverse the scenic Rio Grande National Forest in the San Juan Mountains. We will then finish our adventure with a day at the famous Great Sand Dunes National Park. Be ready for fun days on the snow and ice followed by nights filled with star gazing and board games around the wood stove. We will teach you everything you need to know, so no prior snowshoeing experience is necessary. This trip is perfect for someone who wants to try new adventures, build close friendships, and doesn’t mind the cold. $355 for students/members $605 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Obex
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross March 13-19. Visit theross.org for tickets, showtimes, and more information. In pre-internet 1987, Conor and his dog Sandy live a life of seclusion, lost in the slow-rendering graphics of early Macs and televisions aglow with late night horror movie marathons. But when he begins playing OBEX, a new and mysterious, state-of-the-art computer game, he finds himself trapped in a low-tech, but high-stakes analog hellscape as the line between reality and game blurs. Audacious and uncanny, writer-director Albert Birney's OBEX is a delightfully skewed lo-fi fantasy. Shot in striking black and white, this surreally nostalgic nightmare revisits the dawn of personal computing to reflect on the loneliness of our always-online present day.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Sirat
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross March 13-26. Visit theross.org for tickets, show times, and more information. From writer-director Oliver Laxe (Fire Will Come, Mimosas) comes an explosive and transformative descent into the Moroccan desert, where a Spanish father and his young son infiltrate an underground rave scene in search of a missing girl.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Escalante Canyons Backpacking
events.description: Have you ever wanted to explore the beautiful orange and red canyons, natural arches and desert of the American Southwest? This is the adventure for you! On this trip we will head deep into the canyons of the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument on a five-day backpacking expedition. You will be fully present and immersed in nature as we carry all of our own gear, cook savory backcountry meals, and have great conversations under the stars. We will finish the trip by spending a day exploring and hiking in a National Park. Join us for an unforgettable Spring Break in the awe-inspiring desert southwest! No prior backpacking experience is necessary, and there are many first-time adventurers who have done this trip, though keep in mind is that backpacking is a serious physical activity where you will spend hours walking most days. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 13-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 6:30-8:00pm March 4 & 11, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $495 for students/members $745 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break National Parks Hiking Tour
events.description: Join us for a week of exploring the breathtaking National Parks of the American Southwest on this new Outdoor Adventures trip! We will spend a week hiking in Zion, Canyonlands, and Arches National Parks as well as exploring lesser known, but just as beautiful trails in the surrounding desert. We will be touring the parks on foot, spending the majority of our days hiking to scenic views and overlooks (with plenty of time to soak in the scenery and take pictures). Each night we will cook and camp together as we share stories of that day’s adventure. This is the perfect trip for someone looking to get into hiking and outdoor adventures as well as seasoned explorers interested in checking new National Parks off their bucket list. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 13-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 8:00-9:30pm March 4 & 11, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $525 for students/members $774 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Rio Grande Canoeing
events.description: One word best describes the canyons of West Texas: remote. If you’re seeking a real adventure, you won’t find a better alternative to this Spring Break trip. This trip is a great chance to slow down and decompress, as we spend multiple days on the river, with no resupplies or stops at restaurants in between the put-in and the take-out. You’ll have some great conversations with new friends as you paddle in the tight canyons forged by iconic watersheds of the remote desert and explore side canyons or remains of villages. Find something worth telling stories about when you return from break. Given the remoteness and challenging rapids of this trip, this trip will require participants to be actively involved in paddling and learning how to navigate the rapids. This trip is an opportunity to work through challenges as a team and do significant physical exercise over spring break. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 12-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 7:00-9:00pm March 2 & March 9, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $495 for students/members $745 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Drone Pilot Training - Part 107
events.description: Ready for take-off! This 2-day comprehensive course will prepare you for the FAA Aeronautical Knowledge Test. Also know as the Part 107 exam, this is an essential starting point for anyone planning to fly drones commercially. Our expert instruction and interactive learning materials will guide you through the exam’s complexities, ensuring you are fully prepared to take to the skies as a certified commercial drone pilot. This class will also feature hands-on experience flying drones. Registration Includes: Instructor’s Notes Hands-on Flying Practice Gleim Study Book FAA Remote Pilot Study Guide Part 107 Sample Questions + Many More Digital Tools The FAA requires participants taking the aeronautical knowledge exam be 16 and older, a U.S. citizen, and be able to read and speak English. Cost: $200 Two Day CourseStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: SNAP Sign-up
events.description: Struggling to afford groceries? Join us for one-on-one help signing up for SNAP benefits! Sign up HERE! ************** SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) is a federal program that helps eligible students afford groceries and food. Coordinators from the Food Bank of Lincoln will be on campus to walk you through the SNAP application process and answer all your questions. Whether you're curious about eligibility or ready to apply, they'll help you get started. *************** What to expect: 30 minute meeting slots with personalized support with your SNAP application in a judgement-free environment. Have questions? Reach out to Student Advocacy and Support for more info.Free Food Support Status: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Raíces
events.description: Raices translates to "roots" in Spanish. The term represents the deep cultural heritage and ancestry that is a fundamental part of Hispanic and Latinx identities. The purpose of this group is to provide a safe space for students to receive and offer support, process their experiences, thoughts, feelings and build community with others who can empathize. Raices provides a sense of belonging and connection for participants of all identities who are interested in engaging, acknowledging, and unpacking the unique mental health struggles that individuals of diverse Hispanic and Latin American identities face during their undergraduate studies. All students are welcome at CAPS.4-week Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Stars of American Ballet
events.location: Lied Center for Performing Arts Room:Lied Center Main Stage
events.description: Praised by The Boston Globe as “An unapologetic showcase of virtuosity,” Stars of American Ballet brings together today’s most remarkable ballet talents to highlight the rich diversity and expressive range of contemporary and classical dance. With a program including George Balanchine’s Apollo, Petipa’s timeless White Swan Pas de Deux, and Twyla Tharp’s Brel solo, these works celebrate the artistry, emotion, and versatility that define the evolving landscape of ballet. Featuring a cast of principal and soloist dancers from the New York City Ballet and other renowned companies, in addition to live music for select pieces, this collective returns to the Lied Center celebrating a glorious evening of ballet masterpieces.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross March 20-26. Visit theross.org for tickets, showtimes, and more information. You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine captures a star-studded tribute to the legendary songwriter, filmed in October 2022 at Nashville's Ryman Auditorium. The event brought together acclaimed artists, friends, and family to share behind-the-scenes stories and perform classic songs, honoring Prine's enduring legacy. Prine, widely celebrated as one of history's greatest songwriters, captivated millions of fans and earned the admiration of icons such as Bonnie Raitt, Brandi Carlile, Tyler Childers, Lucinda Williams, Dwight Yoakam, Jason Isbell, and Bob Weir, amongst many others, are featured in the film performing on the Ryman stage for this special celebration of his life and music.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.description: The poultry group in the Department of Animal Science has natural chicken compost for sale. Sold in 15 lb. bags for $5/bag. Payments must be via check or cash (must be exact change). Pick up on Fridays by appointment only. Please contact Megan Carman (mcarman3@unl.edu), Poultry Research Technician, to place an order and to arrange pickup.Status: CONFIRMED | -

events.title: Part 107 Remote Pilot Exam Prep Course
events.description: This 1-day (8-hour) course prepares students to pass the FAA Part 107 Aeronautical Knowledge Exam required to receive a remote pilot certificate (aka drone license). Covers aviation topics such as regulations, airspace, radio communication, weather, aircraft performance, and other basic aviation concepts necessary to pass the exam. Aviation experience is not essential to be successful in the course. This course is geared towards anyone interested in flying drones for commercial or public applications, including agriculture, spray drones, emergency management, law enforcement, real estate and land management, and photography. One-Day Drone Training from Nebraska ExtensionStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Wellbeing Discussions
events.description: A supportive, low-intensity space for Raikes School students to explore a variety of wellbeing-related topics, pause, and reset. We engage in discussion for 20 to 30 minutes, followed by 10 to 15 minutes of guided meditation, and wrap up with 10 to 15 minutes of Q&A or additional discussion. Participants can direct what topics we spend time on. This is an open, drop-in group. Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Spring Break National Parks Hiking Tour
events.description: Join us for a week of exploring the breathtaking National Parks of the American Southwest on this new Outdoor Adventures trip! We will spend a week hiking in Zion, Canyonlands, and Arches National Parks as well as exploring lesser known, but just as beautiful trails in the surrounding desert. We will be touring the parks on foot, spending the majority of our days hiking to scenic views and overlooks (with plenty of time to soak in the scenery and take pictures). This is the perfect trip for someone looking to get into hiking and outdoor adventures as well as seasoned explorers interested in checking new National Parks off their bucket list. Program Date: Overnight Program from March 13-22, 2026 Required Pre-Trip Meetings: 8:00-9:30pm March 4 & 11, 2026 Sign-Up Deadline: 12:00pm March 2, 2026 $525 for students/members $774 for non-members *payment plan available Sign up at: https://crec.unl.edu/activities/adventure-trips OvernightStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Rio Grande Canoeing
events.description: One word best describes the canyons of West Texas: remote. If you’re seeking a real adventure, you won’t find a better alternative to this Spring Break trip. This trip is a great chance to slow down and decompress, as we spend multiple days on the river, with no resupplies or stops at restaurants in between the put-in and the take-out. You’ll have some great conversations with new friends as you paddle in the tight canyons forged by iconic watersheds of the remote desert and explore side canyons or remains of villages. Find something worth telling stories about when you return from break. Given the remoteness and challenging rapids of this trip, this trip will require participants to be actively involved in paddling and learning how to navigate the rapids. This trip is an opportunity to work through challenges as a team and do significant physical exercise over spring break. events.title: Tristan und Isolde (The Met: Live in HD)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross on Saturday, March 21 at 11am and Sunday, March 29 at 11am. Visit theross.org for tickets and more information. After years of anticipation, a truly unmissable event arrives in cinemas worldwide on March 21 as the electrifying Lise Davidsen tackles one of the ultimate roles for dramatic soprano: the Irish princess Isolde in Wagner's transcendent meditation on love and death. Heroic tenor Michael Spyres stars opposite Davidsen as the love-drunk Tristan. The momentous occasion also marks the advent of a new, Met-debut staging by Yuval Sharon-hailed by The New York Times as "the most visionary opera director of his generation" and the first American to direct an opera at the famed Wagner festival in Bayreuth-as well as Music Director Yannick Nzet-Sguin's first time leading Tristan und Isolde at the Met. Mezzo-soprano Ekaterina Gubanova reprises her portrayal of Brangne, alongside bass-baritone Tomasz Konieczny, who sings Kurwenal after celebrated Met appearances in Wagner's Der Fliegende Hollnder and Ring cycle. Bass-baritone Ryan Speedo Green makes an important role debut as King Marke. Ross EventStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Solar System Explorers
events.description: Join UNSM as we explore the solar system in this special, live-narrated planetarium show created by UNL student and Claire M. Hubbard Science Communication Intern Anastasia Erikson. This three-part series will be available for a limited run in the Mueller Planetarium from February to April. Attendees will also receive a special set of Solar System Trading Cards to help continue the intergalactic fun.Mueller Planetarium ShowStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Angels Theatre Company's The Rocket Men
events.location: Lied Center for Performing Arts Room:Carson Theater
events.description: Six women step into the roles of the former Nazis who sent us to the moon to share with us a story about the team that formed the backbone of NASA in the most unlikely of places...North Alabama. Told through the point of view of Heinz- Hermann Koelle, a lesser-known young German rocketeer, who joined this “Operation Paperclip” team several years later, the play explores the dynamic relationship of Wernher von Braun and Koelle as these two have set their sights on space exploration and colonization beyond the moon. Still, as the play counts down to the launch of Apollo 11, Koelle is befriended by a Jewish engineer who is hell-bent on exposing the truth: the Germans’ technology is based on the V-2 rockets built by slave labor more tied to Koelle’s world than he can imagine. A startling new play about the intersection of scientific exploration and moral responsibility, The Rocket Men asks what it means “to be an American”. The Rocket Men is a new play by award-winning playwright Crystal Skillman. This unique production is part of a National New Play Network Rolling World Premiere happening across the country with The Phoenix Theatre, Synchronicity Theatre, and Angels Theatre.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Spring Break Escalante Canyons Backpacking
events.description: Have you ever wanted to explore the beautiful orange and red canyons, natural arches and desert of the American Southwest? This is the adventure for you! On this trip we will head deep into the canyons of the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument on a five-day backpacking expedition. You will be fully present and immersed in nature as we carry all of our own gear, cook savory backcountry meals, and have great conversations under the stars. We will finish the trip by spending a day exploring and hiking in a National Park. Join us for an unforgettable Spring Break in the awe-inspiring desert southwest! No prior backpacking experience is necessary, and there are many first-time adventurers who have done this trip, though keep in mind is that backpacking is a serious physical activity where you will spend hours walking most days. events.title: University of Nebraska Federal Credit Union Presents: Smart Car Buying
events.description: Thinking about buying a new or used vehicle? Make your next car purchase with confidence by attending a Car Buying Webinar, hosted by University of Nebraska Federal Credit Union's Director of Consumer Lending, Mark Priess. Whether you're buying your first car, upgrading your current ride, or simply exploring your options, this free webinar will guide you through the entire process and help you avoid costly mistakes. What You'll Learn: How to determine what you can afford Tips for improving your buying power The pros and cons of new vs. used vehicles How to negotiate price and avoid common dealer add-ons Understanding auto loans, rates, and pre-approval Steps to protect your investment after purchaseStatus: CONFIRMED |

events.title: State of the Agency Lecture
events.description: Justice Funke will speak from 12:30-2:00 on March 24, 2025. Chief Justice Jeffrey J. Funke took office on November 1, 2024. He was appointed to the bench in 2007 as a county court judge in the 2nd Judicial District, and in 2013 was appointed to serve as a district court judge in the 2nd Judicial District. Chief Justice Funke joined the Nebraska Supreme Court as an Associate Justice in 2016. As part of his duties as an associate justice, he was the court's liaison for Nebraska's probation system, problem-solving courts, Nebraska's Lawyer Assistance Program, Bench/Media Committee, and the Nebraska State Bar Commission. Before joining the bench, Chief Justice Funke was in private practice and served in various governmental capacities, including deputy public defender, deputy county attorney and county attorney. B.S., University of Nebraska, 1991. J.D., University of Nebraska College of Law, with honors, 1994.Jeffrey J. Funke, chief justice, Nebraska Supreme CourtStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
events.description: Wellness Recovery Action Plan or WRAP is an evidence-based practice that helps individuals develop a personalized wellness and crisis plan. WRAP takes a strengths-based approach to help individuals take control of their well-being and increase awareness and management of health concerns. Through the course of the group, members will develop their own WRAP and learn skills to support their wellbeing. This is an open group, and members can join at any session. Members are encouraged to continue until all sections of their WRAP are completed.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Alcohol and Drug Harm Reduction Group
events.description: This group is offered to anyone that wants to make positive changes to their substance use. We foster the philosophy that every person is unique and may be in different places with their alcohol and drug use. Therefore, respect and openness to these differences is paramount to how the group is conducted.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Piece by Piece
events.description: Building connections in college can feel challenging, especially when you are feeling overwhelmed. Good news - you don't have to do it alone! Piece by Piece is a group focused on using board games as a fun and low-pressure way to explore interpersonal skills, manage emotions, and develop healthy ways of relating to others. Each session offers an opportunity to learn, reflect, and engage at your own comfort level - no pressure to share or participate beyond what feels comfortable to you. This is an open, drop-in group. Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Engineering Pitch Competition
events.description: Graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln are invited to participate in the 2026 Engineering Pitch Competition. The competition is hosted by the College of Engineering and NUtech Ventures. The Pitch Competition will take place on Tuesday, March 24th, 2026 from 4:30-7:30pm at the College of Engineering's Kiewit Hall, Room A235 on the Lincoln City Campus. Guidelines: Teams can have 1-5 participants, with at least one participant from the UNL College of Engineering. Interdisciplinary teams are strongly encouraged. The team must be focused on solving an engineering problem. Individuals may only register once for this competition and may not compete on more than one team. Judging Criteria and Awards: The competition is judged based on participants' ability to identify an important problem, formulate a value proposition related to solving that problem, estimate market size and describe their business model. Technical details will only be discussed at a very high level. The competition features prizes for the top three finalists. All prize money must be used to further develop the business idea (travel, materials for prototypes, etc.). Info Sessions: In Person - Tuesday March 3rd - Kiewit Hall, A510 - 2:00-3:30PM. Donuts and coffee will be provided. Virtual - Wednesday March 4th - https://go.unl.edu/engineering_pitch_info - 2:00-3:30PM Additional Resources: Pitch Deck: Once you have registered, you will receive a pitch deck template. The pitch deck contains several links to help guide you in your planning, as well as an overall template that every team needs to follow when scripting their presentations. Office Hours: Each team is encouraged to complete at least one office hour/coaching session with an Event Organizer. Please contact one of the Organizers via email to set up a time to meet via Zoom for your coaching session (their contact information is below). More than one office hour/coaching session is allowed and encouraged! Status: CONFIRMED | - |

events.description: ACT is a group co-facilitated by Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD) and Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS). All group meetings will take place every two weeks at the SSD office in Louise Pound Hall room 117 from 5:15 pm to 6:15 pm. This drop-in group is designed to be used to supplement SSD's Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) Transition Program, but no formal diagnosis of ASD is required to attend and students do not have to participate in the Transition Program. Group members are encouraged to bring topics for group discussion on the week's theme and may participate as much or as little as they are comfortable. Group facilitators will also present relaxation and coping skills at the end of each group. Please see the website for future dates and topics.Balancing Work, Academic, and Social LivesStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: A.I. and Ice Cream
events.description: Enjoy free Dairy Store Ice Cream and engage in a conversation with other undergraduate and graduate students about A.I.! Whether you use A.I. tools every day, have sworn them off entirely, or are somewhere in between, the libraries is offering an opportunity for students to share honestly about how A.I. is reshaping our academic work, research and creativity. Join us for a judgement-free discussion about how you're using AI, sharing what excites you, concerns you, and where you think AI is headed in the future. Library staff and faculty will facilitate this conversation. There will be no presentation, lecture or agenda - just open and curious minds (and, of course, ice cream). March 25th from 11:30a - 1pm in the Adele Coryell Learning Commons, behind Dunkin' Donuts. Registration optional, walk-ins welcome. This event is designed as a student-centered conversation for undergraduates and graduate students. Faculty and staff are welcome to attend, but the primary focus - and the treats - are intended for students, as we create a space where peers can openly discuss their own thoughts and experiences with the use of A.I.Status: CONFIRMED | - |

events.description: Ioanna Kipourou [pronounced yo-AH-nah kee-pu-RU] will offer weekly office hours to advise undergraduates on developing a competitive profile and matching their eligibility and interests to specific fellowship or research opportunities. https://uraf.unl.edu/person/ioanna-kipourou/ Drop-in services are available on Wednesdays from 2:00 - 3:30 pm at Nebraska Union 225 D (Career Services/Undergraduate Research & Fellowships), on the following dates: January 21, 28; February 4, 11, 18, 25; March 4, 25; April 1, 15, 22, 29. Drop-In Services are not available in summer, during breaks, or on student holidays. Drop-In Services are typically not optimal for First Year Research Experience (FYRE) student support. Please utilize advising appointments with Ioanna Kipourou, Kali Patterson, or Courtney Santos. Additional Drop-In Services for specific fellowships (Fulbright, Gilman) are available on our URAF events calendar(https://uraf.unl.edu/events/). events.title: Grief Group
events.description: Grief can be an isolating experience. You don't have to go through it alone. CAPS is hosting a weekly Grief Group where all students can find a safe and supportive space to process the death of a friend, family member, or loved one with peers who have had similar experiences. events.title: Nebraska Water Center Spring Seminar Series - Elli Rogan
events.description: On March 25, Elli Rogan will discuss AltEn’s community impact. The Nebraska Water Center (NWC), in partnership with the University of Nebraska-Lincoln’s School of Natural Resources, will begin its annual Spring Water Seminar Series in January. This year’s series will explore how water management shapes our communities, a theme designed to bring together perspectives from across the state to discuss the shared water challenges facing Nebraskans. The Series is open to the public and will be held in Room 901 in Hardin Hall on the University of Nebraska-Lincoln East Campus at 3:30 p.m. The seminar will also be streamed online via Zoom for attendees who are not based in Lincoln and posted on our website. Please contact Ann Briggs at annbriggs@nebraska.edu if you’d like to attend via Zoom. The 2026 seminar dates are January 21, February 4, February 18, March 4, March 25, April 8, and April 22.AltEn’s community impactStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.description: Showing at The Ross March 20-26. Visit theross.org for tickets, showtimes, and more information. You Got Gold: A Celebration of John Prine captures a star-studded tribute to the legendary songwriter, filmed in October 2022 at Nashville's Ryman Auditorium. The event brought together acclaimed artists, friends, and family to share behind-the-scenes stories and perform classic songs, honoring Prine's enduring legacy. Prine, widely celebrated as one of history's greatest songwriters, captivated millions of fans and earned the admiration of icons such as Bonnie Raitt, Brandi Carlile, Tyler Childers, Lucinda Williams, Dwight Yoakam, Jason Isbell, and Bob Weir, amongst many others, are featured in the film performing on the Ryman stage for this special celebration of his life and music.Ross MovieStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Mid-Career Faculty Workshop Series
events.description: Faculty Affairs in the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor and the Office of Research and Innovation plan to offer a new program to support mid-career faculty. The program is built for associate professors, associate professors of practice, and research associate professors. The program is designed to inspire and empower established faculty to grow their impact in research, creative activity, teaching, service, and extension/community engagement, while building a pathway to promotion. The Spring 2026 program will include three 90-minute, in-person workshops. All workshops will be held in the Nebraska Union, Room: Platte River South. (UPDATE: 2/19 meeting has been changed to a virtual event.) * Grow Your Passion, Fuel Your Goals Thursday, February 19, from 2:00 p.m. - 3:30 p.m. (UPDATE: changed to a virtual event. A zoom link will be sent to registrants.) Outcome: Recenter your passion and strengths in the next stage of your career. * Set Your Goals, Plan Your Path Thursday, March 26, from 2:00 p.m. - 3:30 p.m. Outcome: Set inspiring 5-year goals that reflect your strengths, values and identity as a scholar and the mission of you unit. * Gather Your Team, Find Your Support Thursday, April 9, from 2:00 p.m. - 3:30 p.m. Outcome: Identify the people and opportunities that will offer you the insight, resources, and support needed to succeed along your path. Register for one or more of these workshops here: https://research.unl.edu/events/event_nuramp.php?EMSEventUUID=cf832b9a-7f3c-4d2c-9f0f-8e52f25b4451 Questions may be directed to Jennifer PeeksMease (jpeeksmease2@nebraska.edu) or Deb Hamernik (dhamernik2@nebraska.edu). events.title: Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar Lecture
events.description: In honor of the 250th anniversary of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, Professor David M. Rabban, the Dahr Jamail, Randall Hage Jamail, and Robert Lee Jamail Regents Chair in Law and Distinguished Teaching Professor at the University of Texas at Austin, will deliver a lecture on "The Meaning of Academic Freedom as a First Amendment Right of Universities." Rabban has made substantial contributions to the fields of legal history and academic freedom, including his recent book Academic Freedom: From Professional Norm to First Amendment Right. Founded in 1776 at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, Phi Beta Kappa is the oldest and most respected honorary society in the United States with chapters at 293 of the foremost institutions of higher education across the country. The organization recognizes and encourages a commitment to excellence in the liberal arts. The Alpha of Nebraska Chapter was chartered at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln in 1895 and elected its first members in 1896. The membership and activities of the organization have reflected their respective times. The local chapter has held meetings, sponsored occasional programs, talks, and lectures, and elected a full slate of new members. The Meaning of Academic Freedom as a First Amendment Right of UniversitiesStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

Experience deep relaxation, an increased sense of well-being, expanded awareness, and inner peace. This session will take place in the Nebraska Union - Chimney Rock Room. events.title: Artist Talk: Binh Danh
events.description: San Jose-based artist Binh Danh, whose photographs are featured in the exhibition "Hyphen American: Intersection of Identity," returns to Sheldon Museum of Art to deliver a talk on his career and artistic practice. Danh first came to Nebraska in 2011 as an artist-in-residence at Sheldon, during which time he created works for the solo exhibition "Viet Nam, Nebraska." Danh's talk, presented as part of the Hixson-Lied Visiting Artist & Scholar Lecture Series in collaboration with the School of Art, Art History & Design, will reflect on the transformational period spent working on "Viet Nam, Nebraska" and the evolution of his artistic practice since then. The talk is free and open to the public; registration is encouraged.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Part 107 Remote Pilot Exam Prep Course
events.description: This 1-day (8-hour) course prepares students to pass the FAA Part 107 Aeronautical Knowledge Exam required to receive a remote pilot certificate (aka drone license). Covers aviation topics such as regulations, airspace, radio communication, weather, aircraft performance, and other basic aviation concepts necessary to pass the exam. Aviation experience is not essential to be successful in the course. This course is geared towards anyone interested in flying drones for commercial or public applications, including agriculture, spray drones, emergency management, law enforcement, real estate and land management, and photography. events.title: Teach-in: The Myth of the American Dream
events.description: Gabriel Bruguier, assistant professor and research specialist librarian at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Libraries, leads a teach-in examining the myth of the American dream. This teach-in is an interactive, multidisciplinary engagement with artist Nicholas Galanin's work "The American Dream is Alie and Well," which is featured in the exhibition "Hyphen American: Intersections of Identity" at Sheldon Museum of Art. This teach-in is free and open to individuals 16 years and older. Space is limited, and registration is required. About Gabriel Bruguier Gabriel Bruguier is an assistant professor and teaching and learning librarian at the University of Nebraska Libraries. He is an enrolled member of the Yankton Sioux Tribe and grew up in Vermillion and Sisseton, South Dakota. He holds MA and PhD degrees in philosophy from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, a BA in philosophy from the University of Minnesota, Morris, and a Licentiate in International Relations from the Universidad de las Americas-Puebla. He is the City of Lincoln Commissioner on the Nebraska Commission on Indian Affairs. Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Tristan und Isolde (The Met: Live in HD)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross on Saturday, March 21 at 11am and Sunday, March 29 at 11am. Visit theross.org for tickets and more information. After years of anticipation, a truly unmissable event arrives in cinemas worldwide on March 21 as the electrifying Lise Davidsen tackles one of the ultimate roles for dramatic soprano: the Irish princess Isolde in Wagner's transcendent meditation on love and death. Heroic tenor Michael Spyres stars opposite Davidsen as the love-drunk Tristan. The momentous occasion also marks the advent of a new, Met-debut staging by Yuval Sharon-hailed by The New York Times as "the most visionary opera director of his generation" and the first American to direct an opera at the famed Wagner festival in Bayreuth-as well as Music Director Yannick Nzet-Sguin's first time leading Tristan und Isolde at the Met. Mezzo-soprano Ekaterina Gubanova reprises her portrayal of Brangne, alongside bass-baritone Tomasz Konieczny, who sings Kurwenal after celebrated Met appearances in Wagner's Der Fliegende Hollnder and Ring cycle. Bass-baritone Ryan Speedo Green makes an important role debut as King Marke. Ross EventStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
events.description: Wellness Recovery Action Plan or WRAP is an evidence-based practice that helps individuals develop a personalized wellness and crisis plan. WRAP takes a strengths-based approach to help individuals take control of their well-being and increase awareness and management of health concerns. Through the course of the group, members will develop their own WRAP and learn skills to support their wellbeing. This is an open group, and members can join at any session. Members are encouraged to continue until all sections of their WRAP are completed.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Alcohol and Drug Harm Reduction Group
events.description: This group is offered to anyone that wants to make positive changes to their substance use. Abstinence is not required, although individuals committed to a sober lifestyle are welcome to attend. Whatever your goals are, the choice is yours for how you want to engage in the group. We foster the philosophy that every person is unique and may be in different places with their alcohol and drug use. Therefore, respect and openness to these differences is paramount to how the group is conducted.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Piece by Piece
events.description: Building connections in college can feel challenging, especially when you are feeling overwhelmed. Good news - you don't have to do it alone! Piece by Piece is a group focused on using board games as a fun and low-pressure way to explore interpersonal skills, manage emotions, and develop healthy ways of relating to others. Each session offers an opportunity to learn, reflect, and engage at your own comfort level - no pressure to share or participate beyond what feels comfortable to you. This is an open, drop-in group. Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: E.N. Thompson Forum: "America’s Upswing" with Shaylyn Romney Garrett
events.description: Shaylyn Romney Garrett is a celebrated author, speaker, and social entrepreneur whose work offers a fresh take on political polarization, social isolation, economic inequality, and culture change. Her award-winning book, The Upswing: How America Came Together a Century Ago and How We Can Do It Again, coauthored with Robert Putnam, offers an energizing and deeply researched message of hope during a dark time in America’s history. Her commentary has appeared in various outlets including NPR, PBS Newshour, the BBC, Deseret Magazine, TIME Magazine and the New York Times. Romney Garrett holds a degree in Government from Harvard University and has served in the Peace Corps. She spent six years in Jordan working to catalyze youth social innovation there. Upon returning to the U.S., she helped found “Weave: The Social Fabric Project” at the Aspen Institute with David Brooks. She is a member of the Braver Angels Scholars Council, Citizen University’s Civic Collaboratory, and the Faith Matters Initiative Advisory Board. Based on her award-winning book co-written with Robert Putnam, Shaylyn Romney Garrett’s presentation offers an evidence-based roadmap for how to reweave our tattered social fabric. Through stories and data drawn from over a century of history, Garrett speaks passionately about how everyday Americans once changed the course of our nation by building a culture of “we”—and can do it again. Co-sponsor: Center for Great Plains StudiesStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: ServSafe® Training
events.description: The purpose of the ServSafe(R) Food Safety Program is to help food service operations protect public health by preventing foodborne illness and promoting safe food-handling practices. In response to increased publicity surrounding foodborne illness outbreaks and growing consumer concern, this program provides nationally recognized, science-based training developed by the National Restaurant Association. Through ServSafe(R) Manager and ServSafe(R) Food Handler training, participants gain the knowledge and skills needed to provide safe food, reduce contamination risks, and maintain clean, sanitary facilities. The program prepares managers and employees to implement effective food safety management systems, follow proper purchasing, storage, preparation, service procedures, cleaning and sanitation, and train staff in best practices. Intended Audience: The ServSafe(R) Food Safety Program, developed by the National Restaurant Association, addresses growing food safety concerns by providing science-based training for food service professionals. ServSafe(R) Manager is designed for food service managers and supervisors in restaurants, hospitals, schools, long-term care facilities, and other food-handling operations. It offers nationally recognized certification and covers current food safety principles and best practices. ServSafe(R) Food Handler is a basic food safety course for food service employees. It covers essential topics including personal hygiene, cross-contamination and allergens, time and temperature control, and cleaning and sanitation. Certification: By successfully completing the ServSafe(R) Food Safety Program training, food service professionals can earn National Restaurant Association certification, update their food safety skills using the latest FDA Food Code guidance, and strengthen their operation's commitment to food safety and customer confidence.In-PersonStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: 2026 Conference: Great Plains Futures
events.description: For five decades, the Center for Great Plains Studies has elevated the region as a place worthy of study, appreciation, and conservation. For our 50th anniversary, the annual Great Plains conference will celebrate our past and look to the next 50 years and beyond. This conference invites us to dream big about the future of people and land in our region. Join us for an interdisciplinary conference featuring keynotes, panels, workshops, and special events in Lincoln, Neb. As we look to explore the future of the region, keynotes and panels will focus on four interconnected themes: environmental futures, re-imagining the rural, Indigenous futures, and demographic change and migration. Keynotes: Danielle Boyer, "From Bytes to Bright Futures: Meet the SkoBots" Join Anishinaabe (Sault Tribe) youth robotics inventor Danielle Boyer as she explores how culturally grounded technology can reshape education, empower communities, and revitalize languages. Growing up under the poverty line and witnessing firsthand the barriers to technical education, Danielle created the SkoBots, wearable, personal language-learning robots to teach Anishinaabemowin. Built with affordability, sustainability, and cultural relevance in mind, her robots cost less than $100 to produce and are distributed free to Indigenous youth. Danielle shares how she has reached over one million students globally, disbursed tens of thousands of robots, and built a movement rooted in community, grassroots innovation, and intergenerational knowledge. J.S. Onsimo (Ness) Sndoval, "Demography as an Analytic Lens: Latino Population Growth and the Demographic Transformation of the Midwest" This talk explores how Latino population growth is reshaping the social, economic, and political landscape of the Midwest. By examining historical settlement patterns, contemporary demographic shifts, and projected trends, it highlights how Latindad has become an essential force driving regional transformation. Using demography as an analytic lens, the presentation connects statistical evidence with lived experience to reveal the far-reaching economic and political consequences of demographic change showing how Latino are redefining the future of Midwestern identity, governance, and opportunity. Shaylyn Romney Garrett, "America's Upswing" Co-hosted with the E.N. Thompson Forum on World Issues at the Lied Center for Performing Arts. Separate (free) tickets required. Social entrepreneur and coauthor of "The Upswing: How America Came Together a Century Ago and How We Can Do It Again," Garrett has shared her opinions, writing, and research in numerous outlets including TIME Magazine, The New York Times, National Public Radio, BBC Radio, and the PBS Newshour. Her nonprofit work has been featured by the New York Times, FastCompany, LinkedIn, and Harvard Business Review. Neil Linscheid, "Community Usability: Designing Communities for People (And Not the Other Way Around)" What makes a community truly work for the people who live there? Across the Midwest and beyond, communities are moving past simply collecting data about newcomers, residents, and entrepreneurs. They're using that information to fundamentally redesign how their towns and cities function. This talk examines what's working, what's not, and what we can learn from communities that are getting it right. We'll look at communities that have reimagined how newcomers access essential services, how entrepreneurs navigate local systems, and how long-time residents connect with changing resources. We'll also examine what happens when communities stop designing for an idealized resident and start designing for the real, diverse people already there. Carol Graham, "Success in Conservation; Partnering with Producers and Private Landowners" Manitoba Habitat Conservancy (MHC) has been delivering conservation programs on private lands across southern Manitoba for 40 years. Enhancing habitat for species at risk and managing wetlands for waterfowl has required partnerships with producers, landowners, and industry. An emphasis on a collaborative approach has resulted in successful securement, enhancement, and mitigation of wildlife habitats in Manitoba. This community approach not only maintains ecological integrity and promotes biodiversity but also ensures ecosystem resilience and long-term ecological stability, beneficial for both producers and private landowners. Graham will speak about lessons learned and successes achieved over the years with programs that target native grassland management for wildlife and livestock production, upland enhancement for nesting habitats, and wetland retention and restoration for waterfowl. Our partners and supporters include: E.N. Thompson Forum on World Issues, UNL Department of Sociology, UNL Office of Research and Innovation, UNL School of Global Integrative Studies, UNL Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts, UNL Department of Biological Systems Engineering, UNL Dean of Engineering, UNL School of Natural Resources, The Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center, Humanities Nebraska, UNL Faculty Senate Convocations Committee, and Editor World LLC. Presented in partnership with the Consulate General of Canada in Minneapolis. 51st Annual Great Plains ConferenceStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

Drop-In Services are not available in summer, during breaks, or on student holidays. Drop-In Services are typically not optimal for First Year Research Experience (FYRE) student support. Please utilize advising appointments with Ioanna Kipourou, Kali Patterson, or Courtney Santos. Additional Drop-In Services for specific fellowships (Fulbright, Gilman) are available on our URAF events calendar(https://uraf.unl.edu/events/). events.title: Grief Group
events.description: Grief can be an isolating experience. You don't have to go through it alone. CAPS is hosting a weekly Grief Group where all students can find a safe and supportive space to process the death of a friend, family member, or loved one with peers who have had similar experiences. Grief Group will learn about grief, explore and process grief's complex emotions, and learn healthy ways to cope. There is no pressure to share or engage, as we are all at different stages in our grieving journey.Drop-In GroupStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Reading by Roque Raquel Salas Rivera
events.description: Roque Raquel Salas Rivera reads from his new book, "Algaraba: The Song of Cenex, Natural Son of the Isle Alarabyya," an epic poem that follows the journey of Cenex, a trans being who retrospectively narrates his life while navigating the stories told on his behalf. An inhabitant of Algaraba, a colony of Earth in a parallel universe, Cenex struggles to find a name, a body, and a stable home. The song of Cenex weaves and clashes texts by cis writers on trans figures with fragments from historical, legal, and other nonliterary texts. Cenex leads us through his childhood hospitalization, his years as an experimental subject, a brief stay in suburbia, twisted meanderings, and not-so-far-off lands accompanied by a merry band of chosen queers. Referencing everything from pop culture to Taino cosmology and philosophy (at times in a single line), this book laughs at its own survival with sharp, unserious rage. The edition is composed of two original texts-one written in the Puerto Rican dialect of Spanish, the other in a reconsideration of English. "Algaraba" inscribes an origin narrative for trans people in the face of their erasure from both colonial and anti-colonial literary canons. Algaraba es una epopeya que sigue el viaje de Cenex, un ser trans que narra su vida retrospectivamente mientras navega por las historias contadas en su nombre. Habitante de Algaraba, una colonia de la Tierra en un universo paralelo, Cenex lucha por encontrar un nombre, un cuerpo y un hogar estables. El canto de Cenex entreteje y enfrenta textos de escritores cis sobre figuras trans con fragmentos de textos histricos, documentos legales y otras fuentes extraliterarias. Su protagonista nos conduce a travs de su hospitalizacin temprana, sus aos como sujeto experimental, una breve estancia suburbana, meandros retorcidos y unas tierras no tan lejanas en la compaa de un grupo jovial de cuirs predilectos. Poblado de referencias a la cultura popular, la cosmologa tana y la filosofa (a veces dentro de un mismo verso), este libro se re de su propia supervivencia con una rabia pcara y aguda. La epopeya se compone de dos textos originales: uno que fue escrito en espaol puertorriqueo y el otro que fue escrito en un ingls alterado. Algaraba inscribe un origen para las personas trans ante su exclusin de los cnones literarios coloniales y anticoloniales. Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: The Audience (National Theatre)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross on Wednesday, April 1 at 7:15pm and Sunday, April 5 at 1:00pm. Visit theross.org for tickets and more information. Returning to cinemas for the first time in over a decade, Helen Mirren plays Queen Elizabeth II in the Olivier and Tony Award(R) -winning hit production, directed by Stephen Daldry. For 60 years, Queen Elizabeth II met with each of her 12 prime ministers in a private weekly meeting. This meeting is known as The Audience. From Winston Churchill to Margaret Thatcher and David Cameron, the Queen advised her prime ministers on matters both public and personal. Through these private audiences, we see glimpses of the woman behind the crown and witness the moments that shaped a monarch. Peter Morgan's Netflix phenomenon The Crown was based on this hit play that was captured live from London's West End in 2013 and went on to become one of the most-watched NT Live productions.Ross EventStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: NRICH: From Goals to Growth: Strategies for Turning Intention into Consistent Action
events.description: We set goals all the time—through evaluations, professional development plans, and the daily, weekly, and monthly responsibilities that shape our work. But after the goals are written and the plans are made, what happens next? Even with a detailed roadmap, sticking to our intentions can be challenging. Initial motivation often feels strong, but as time passes and new priorities emerge, our commitment can fade. This session explores why motivation naturally fluctuates and provides practical strategies for maintaining consistency and self-accountability. Together, we’ll identify approaches that align with your personal work style so you can make steady, realistic progress on the goals and intentions that matter most. The University of Nebraska-Lincoln is committed to accessibility in our events and programs. We provide accommodations for individuals with disabilities to participate effectively and safely. To request an accommodation, please contact Organizational Development and Training by phone at 402.472.3790 or email at training@unl.edu. A minimum of two weeks’ advance notice is preferred to assist us in coordinating accommodation requests. Click the below link to register: Status: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Popcorn Pop-Up
events.description: The best hour of the week! Every Thursday from 3 to 4 p.m. pop into The Crib for an afternoon social hour with 100s of other Huskers. It’s free and every student, staff, and faculty is welcome. Snack on fresh-popped popcorn straight from the kettle. Join in the game/activity while learning about campus organizations and departments. Mingle with friends and new acquaintances. Pencil the Popcorn Pop-Ups into your schedule. Organize your friends to make it a weekly chance to socialize together and chill. ********** WHAT TO EXPECT: Fun, fellowship, laughter, friends, and smiles. The game/activity will be different each week. It might be trivia, or maybe a sport, a craft, or karaoke. You have to show up each week to find out. View the upcoming schedule: https://go.unl.edu/pop-up There will always be fresh popcorn. Anticipate a few surprises from time to time, including special flavors and mix-ins. ********** Earn a spot in the GOLDEN KERNEL CLUB. events.title: Humanities on the Edge presents: Roque Raquel Salas Rivera
events.description: Roque Raquel Salas Rivera, assistant professor of comparative literature at the University of Puerto Rico–Mayagüez presents the last of four Humanities on the Edge lectures. The talk is free and open to the public. Now in its 16th year, the lecture series was founded in 2010 and continues to promote cross-disciplinary conversation and theoretical research in the humanities. The lectures are organized by Katie Anania (art history), Luis Othoniel Rosa (modern languages and literatures and the Institute for Ethnic Studies), Marco Abel (English), and Erin Hanas (Sheldon Museum of Art). Sponsors include the departments of English and Modern Languages and Literatures; School of Art, Art History and Design; Institute for Ethnic Studies; Women’s and Gender Studies Program; Johnny Carson Center for Emerging Media Arts; University of Nebraska–Lincoln Faculty Senate and Research Council; and Sheldon Museum of Art.Anguila Translations and Slippery Gender PracticesStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.description: Get ready for a bagpipe-powered concert like you’ve never seen before! The Red Hot Chilli Pipers (yes, pipers) fuse traditional Scottish music with classic rock anthems—from Queen to AC/DC—with explosive energy and humor. “Bagpipes with attitude, drums with a Scottish accent, and a show that leaves you breathless!” — BBC Scotland. A global phenomenon that’s equal parts rock concert and Highland fling— prepare to be blown away.Status: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: The Audience (National Theatre)
events.location: Mary Riepma Ross Media Arts Center-Van Brunt Visitors Center Room:Ross Theaters (123 & 124)
events.description: Showing at The Ross on Wednesday, April 1 at 7:15pm and Sunday, April 5 at 1:00pm. Visit theross.org for tickets and more information. Returning to cinemas for the first time in over a decade, Helen Mirren plays Queen Elizabeth II in the Olivier and Tony Award(R) -winning hit production, directed by Stephen Daldry. For 60 years, Queen Elizabeth II met with each of her 12 prime ministers in a private weekly meeting. This meeting is known as The Audience. From Winston Churchill to Margaret Thatcher and David Cameron, the Queen advised her prime ministers on matters both public and personal. Through these private audiences, we see glimpses of the woman behind the crown and witness the moments that shaped a monarch. Peter Morgan's Netflix phenomenon The Crown was based on this hit play that was captured live from London's West End in 2013 and went on to become one of the most-watched NT Live productions.Ross EventStatus: CONFIRMED | |

events.title: Wellness Recovery Action Plan (WRAP)
events.description: Wellness Recovery Action Plan or WRAP is an evidence-based practice that helps individuals develop a personalized wellness and crisis plan. Through the course of the group, members will develop their own WRAP and learn skills to support their wellbeing. This is an open group, and members can join at any session. events.description: All UNL faculty, staff, postdoctoral fellows, and students are invited to an interactive panel on effective mentoring practices in STEM. events.title: Autism Connections in Transition (ACT) Drop-In Group
events.description: ACT is a group co-facilitated by Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD) and Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS). All group meetings will take place every two weeks at the SSD office in Louise Pound Hall room 117 from 5:15 pm to 6:15 pm. This drop-in group is designed to be used to supplement SSD's Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) Transition Program, but no formal diagnosis of ASD is required to attend and students do not have to participate in the Transition Program. Group members are encouraged to bring topics for group discussion on the week's theme and may participate as much or as little as they are comfortable. Group facilitators will also present relaxation and coping skills at the end of each group. Please see the website for future dates and topics.Knowing When to Use Coping Strategies, and Which OnesStatus: CONFIRMED | - |

events.title: Nebraska Water Center Spring Seminar Series - Jesse Bradley
events.description: On April 8, Jesse Bradley will provide an update on the Governor’s water task force. The Nebraska Water Center (NWC), in partnership with the University of Nebraska-Lincoln’s School of Natural Resources, will begin its annual Spring Water Seminar Series in January. This year’s series will explore how water management shapes our communities, a theme designed to bring together perspectives from across the state to discuss the shared water challenges facing Nebraskans. The Series is open to the public and will be held in Room 901 in Hardin Hall on the University of Nebraska-Lincoln East Campus at 3:30 p.m. The seminar will also be streamed online via Zoom for attendees who are not based in Lincoln and posted on our website. Please contact Ann Briggs at annbriggs@nebraska.edu if you’d like to attend via Zoom. The 2026 seminar dates are January 21, February 4, February 18, March 4, March 25, April 8, and April 22. Update on the Governor’s water task forceStatus: CONFIRMED | - |
